data.title: Marathon Neighborhood News
data.meta_description: 6 posts published by marathonneighborhoodnews during May 2024
data.text:
Memorial Day weekend was a busy one for many! Some folks needed to go to work on Tuesday to “rest up”.

There were plants to plant in yards and at the cemetery, lawns to mow, hay to cut, lake properties to open for the season, garage tools reorganized from winter to summer, windows to be washed and the list goes on.

Fingers were crossed that rain would not deter the Memorial Day Ceremony on the Village Green. It worked! No rain, but later in the early afternoon it poured.

Last year during the Memorial observance, Commander Arnold was chastised by an on looker that was dismayed about the wreath cast in the river for those who died at sea. The wreath was not biodegradable she said!

This year the Commander was prepared with a grapevine wreath. A grapevine wreath?? A plain ole grapevine wreath? True, it is biodegradable but the ladies of the American Legion Auxiliary were not going to allow a plain ole brown wreath.

What could those ladies do in a short period of time to make that wreath more appealing and worthy? The ladies were on the Village Green and the ceremony was going to begin in a few minutes!

“Necessity is the Mother of Invention” so with boots on the ground the ladies took courage and improvised. Lynn Zelsnack and Hope Cross saw the beautiful iris blossoms around the gazebo. Bert Zurbruegg ran to her car and pulled out garden snippers and cut them. Robin Quail started taking photos. Someone looked up the street to see the big rhododendron blossoms, so they were snipped and added. Lynn had some string in her car and by the time David Quail got back from looking for something to use to attach the blossoms, it was all put together! Yes indeed, those patriots created something worthy to be cast in memory of those who perished at sea. David took their photo. We are proud to publish it. (l-r) Hope Cross, Lynn Zelsnack, Robin Quail and Bert Zurbruegg.

The Marathon High School Marching Band played the National Anthem and taps with an echo as wreaths were placed on the Village Green, cast into the water of the Tioughnioga and at the flagpole in the Marathon Cemetery. It is so nice to have the band a part of the ceremony and to lead the parade. Walkers followed the band. David Lusk, a 90 year old Veteran was driven in a golf cart up to the Cemetery, Justin Lilley at the wheel.

Veteran Kevin Moore carried the American Flag all the way to the Cemetery. Along the way some band members had to step to the side and let the parade go by, due to being over heated. The traditional walk to the Cemetery is a hike, we are proud of those who did it! Local photographer, Yvonne Moore captured the laying of the wreath at the Cemetery’s flagpole, with Veterans Bill Perfitt and John Walburn doing the honors. At the end of the ceremony, Veterans (l-r) John Walburn, Jim Robinson, Kevin Moore and Bill Perfitt rolled up the flags.

Working together Marathon had a very nice Memorial Day Ceremony. Thank you Mayor Chamberlin and the Village Electric Department for improving the sound system at the gazebo.

Did you know that our Mayor walks in the Village every day? It is very easy to “grab his ear”as he passes by. He is proud of the many volunteers who make Marathon a great place to live.

Now the wild flox are showing their beauty and no doubt are the reason the Indians gave our river it’s name- Tioughnioga- “flowers along the banks”.

Village folks are asking drivers, especially on Galatia Street, headed to the McGraw-Marathon Road to slow down, there is no need to speed on those narrow streets.

Village folks are also complaining of unleashed dogs who wander and use lawns as their “sand box”. That really isn’t fair! Dog owners have a responsibility to know where their dog is, preferably on their own property.

Another disturbing happening along Highland Road occurred sometime on Memorial Day. For too many years to count, Veteran David Lusk has proudly displayed on his lawn, on Memorial Day, a number of flags: the Bennington Flag, Betsy Ross Flag, the 50 star American Flag and the Confederate Flag. When Dave came home following the Memorial Day Ceremony the Confederate Flag was missing. Just that one. Dave will have a 90th Birthday Party on Sunday, and he has had that flag since he was a little boy. Wouldn’t it be sweet if it could be returned by the person who took it?

June is Dairy Month. Next Tuesday the Marathon High School Band will participate in a Parade in the City of Cortland.

Love gardening, especially flowers? Want to join with others who feel the same way? Be on Lovell Field’s parking lot June 7 (next Friday) to car pool to Grisamore Garden Nursery in Locke, New York at 9:30 a.m. Bring a bag lunch to enjoy at Fillmore Glen State Park, located in Moravia.

Sympathy of the community is extended to the family of Sandra Rae Johnson Davids, MCS Class of 1960, daughter of the late Russell and Joyce Johnson, who passed away November 10, 2023 in Media, Pennsylvania at age 81. Sandra grew up on the family farm in Freetown with siblings Kathryn, Robert and David. She was active in 4-H mastering, cooking, sewing, gardening and animal husbandry. Sandra was also active in school, at one time held the shot-put record, she also taught Sunday School at the nearby Freetown Methodist Church. She and her first husband Charles Frisbee brought a son and daughter into the world. Sandra had a 30 year career with IBM. Her cremains were brought home to Freetown where they were interred in the Freetown Cemetery, with a private ceremony held on Saturday, May 25 in the cemetery. Her late husband James Davids (32 years) who passed away 8/18/22, and their two pet’s cremains were also interred there.

Brother Tom Boice officiated at the beautiful ceremony with music, poems and fine tributes to the lives of Sandra and James.

Did you get your reservation made for the 133rd Marathon Alumni Banquet on June 22nd? Payment is to be made ahead of time, no payment at the door. This year the buffet dinner is $25.

The Alumni Committee is asking graduates to get involved and consider participating in the organization, which is dedicated to carrying on the tradition of hosting a banquet which gives an opportunity for former graduates to come together again with their classmates. Go to olympianalumni@yahoo.com with questions and to make arrangements to attend.

The Christian Academy’s Pre-School will celebrate Grandparents Day on Thursday June 6th at 10 a.m. This is always a special occasion and anyone who appreciates the accomplishments of little people will be so happy to be in the audience for their performance.

The Annual Strawberry Shortcake Sale for Peck Memorial Library’s Children’s Program is Thursday June 6 starting at 3 p.m. in front of the Methodist Church. It is a good idea to pre-order by calling 849-6135. Just $5.

The families of MCS Class of 2024 graduates are busy planning family celebrations. We wish each member of the Class of 2024 good luck with finals and happy days during their last days of school, as they wrap their heads around the fact that life as they have known it is about to change.

We wish a speedy healing to Bill Tei who has broken a hip and expects to be in rehab at Cortland Memorial Medical Center (Guthrie).

We wish a speedy recovery from recent eye surgery to Pat Willis.

We wish a “get home soon” to Cheryl Pfeifer who is recovering from heart surgery.

We ask you to be a good neighbor and to check on your neighbor. Celebrate June with lots of ice cream. In fact, get out the ice cream maker and make it. Until next time, milk with cookies is a nice combo too!

There is a mad scramble going on out there! It is on lawns, gardens, cemeteries, hay fields, and all the outdoors! Folks are mowing lawns, edging, trimming and planting. Folks with swimming pools have the Marathon Firemen filling them up. Farmers are chopping the first hay crop! It is a busy time of year!

Everyone knows the Lily of the Valley!

The wild flowers are are blooming too. Sure everyone knows the Buttercups, and the wild strawberry plants but do you know the name of the pink ones? They are dotting the countryside too!

The Annual Marathon Lions Club’s plant sale, was very successful this year. We know what folks will be doing on Memorial weekend. They will be finding just the right spot to plant these beauties. Rhea Robinson (l) helps Brianne Shippey (r) fill the order that Little Leaguer Parker Shippey sold.

On Tuesday, 344 Marathon Central School Taxpayers, went to the polls. Twenty-one voters voted by Absentee Ballots.

Kimberly Moore and Justin Lilley filed petitions and were on the ballot. A write-in campaign, by Floyd Parker, former member of the Marathon School Board, was successful, edging out Miss Moore. Final results were Justin Lilley-281, Floyd Parker 242, Kimberly Moore 91.

Superintendent Buchsbaum was very happy that all propositions passed. Budget passed 270 to 64, Buses passed 272 to 63 and Technology Reserve 268 to 61. Mr. Buchsbaum smiled saying “I guess it was a good idea that the new buses will be diesel, not electric.”

Take a look at this!

Dave Roe, of R & M Farm & Pro Hardware, is the proud owner of The Perfection Cooler & Aerator! What? Got you stumped? Wonder what it was used for and how it works?

Dave has been in the “milk” business all of his life, in one way or another, but this piece of equipment is way before his time.

A busy man for sure, but Dave realized this is a piece of dairy farmer history and was in the right place at the right time to save it. Now he will tackle the skill of removing rust. Dave has done extensive research, knows who invented it and even found that the inventor lived in Marathon at one time. Lynn R. Lewis was a man of many traits and talents. He was even elected Mayor in the City of Cortland on the Prohibition Party line!

Dave wants to give this piece of dairy farming history to a place where people can see it and appreciate the time in which it was invented. The Marathon Area Historical Society has guaranteed Dave that it will be on display at the 1890 Union Fair and at the FFA Fair on the Village Green. The Society believes that The Perfection Cooler & Aerator may have been key for local dairy farmers who shipped milk to NYC! “George and Jerome Hulbert made their living from buying milk, cheese, eggs from local farmers, then shipping to NYC to a third brother who sold it there. Both men, are mentioned in The Gripp’s History of Marathon” said Village Historian Connie White.

The Class of 1972 held their monthly “reunion” get together at Reilly’s Café on Friday, May 17th. “We meet about once a month, in a variety of places, but Reilly’s Café is our home turf” said Mary Gordon Glezen. “We will meet the third Friday in June, but in July it will be the second Friday because Allan Knoezer will be here from Florida and Pat McCracken will be here from Georgia. We have so much fun, no clicks, we are all the same. At our 50th Reunion, 35 out of 49 attended. We even had a fun water fight at that reunion.” (l-r) Going around the table -Bruce ?, Sue Reagan, Hazel McCalister, Steve Col, Dale Smith, Ed Barry, Diane Sturdevant, Terry Schumacher, Mary Gordon and Aimee Peppin.

Eagle Scout candidate, Alexander Votra began his Eagle project last weekend. His project will benefit the Marathon Lions Club’s Little League Program. He has coordinated and managed everything, from getting quotes to enlisting volunteers, to replace the roof on the Little League’s Snack Shack and bathrooms on Lovell Field. Alexander is keeping detailed information about every aspect of the project. That information will be presented to a review board to determine if the project is worthy of the prestigious “Eagle Scout” badge.

Donna Hughes and Barb Elwyn are committed to making Peck Memorial Library’s back yard neat and tidy. The two ladies worked all day there on Sunday. Sure does look nice with the new fence.

Meet Dorothy Duff a lady who knows how to get things done! She walks with a walker to the Post Office daily. We asked if we could help her with a large package she just received in the Post Office. But Dorothy proudly pulled out her bungy cords and said she was prepared! “When you live alone, you figure out ways to get things done” she said. Sure enough, we next caught up with her on the Village Green, proudly taking her package home. Right on Dorothy!

Thursday evening, the Marathon Cemetery was a beehive of activity as volunteers placed flags on the graves of Veterans.

As the Legion Volunteers left the cemetery in came Fireman Floyd Parker honoring Firemen’s graves with a special red/yellow flag.

Main Street looks more inviting with the arrival of the flower barrels that the Marathon Lions Club makes possible. Lion Jim Robinson is Chairman of that committee, which sprang into action Thursday evening following decorating the graves in the cemetery. (l-r) Steve Robinson, Jim Robinson, CJ Saplin, Kevin Moore and Rhea Robinson, right after all the flower barrels were placed along Main Street.

Barbara Elwyn was fixing the urns at Peck Memorial Library on Thursday morning. Across the street on the Village Green, History Teacher Bill Perks was escorting some of his students to the Civil War Monument, no doubt discussing the history of how Decoration Day which became Memorial Day !

Mayor Scott Chamberlin walks around the Village every day. He was happy to see everyone getting ready for Memorial Day.

Now the Japanese Iris, the rhododendrons, and soon the peonies will be taking the spotlight. The lilacs send out their sweet smell and isn’t it wonderful that Jack Frost did not freeze the apple blossoms, which means we just may have a very good apple crop.

Make sure you are on the Village Green, on Monday, Memorial Day. Buy a poppy from the Ladies Auxiliary, walk in the parade to the cemetery, get your family, friends and neighborhood to join in. We ask you to be a good neighbor and to check on your neighbor. Walk in the Memorial Day parade with the Marathon High School Band. Until next time, honor all Veterans!

“I’ll be with you in apple blossom time

I’ll be with you to change your name to mine”

Boy, they sure don’t write songs like that anymore, can you finish the next two lines of that old song?

Yes it is apple blossom time and it is time for so much more. Little white strawberry blossoms dot lawns and fields, they are mixed with dandelions, along with blue and white violets too. Rhubarb lovers are harvesting rhubarb, and in a few weeks the strawberries will be added to the pie for the famous strawberry/rhubarb pie.

Moms were celebrated on Sunday in a variety of family occasions. Moms were remembered and celebrated. Moms received cards, flowers, special breakfasts, dinner invitations, visits, and more.

The Senior Class returned home late Friday evening from the Senior Class Trip and a good time was had by all. It was a total of 33 students with Chaperones: Heather Euson, Kacie Penrose, Louann Kash, Aubrey Brown, Steve Riggs and Jonelle Sturdevant. This was a wonderful opportunity to be in Florida with classmates and friends.

MCS Auditorium on Monday evening hosted the Annual School Budget and Meet the Candidates night. Superintendent Buchsbaum and Business Manager Goskoski presented a zero (O) increase budget. Taxpayers need to know that 70% of the MCS Budget is NYS funded.

The two candidates for School Board, that are on the ballot were invited to speak. Kimberly Moore and Justin Lilley. This is Kimberly’s first time running for public office. Justin is seeking a second term.

Following the public hearing everyone was invited to the High School Library for the May meeting of the Board of Education. During community input time, High School Teacher Robin Visco spoke on behalf of the MCS Teachers, who wished to thank the Board for their daily recognition of “Teacher Appreciation Week”.

Other items for the Community Input were:

The American Sign Language Class which is directed by Town Clerk Doris Adams and Appleby Speech Teacher Stacy Soda, signed the alphabet, the school song and more for the Board of Education. (they received a standing ovation)

Elementary Instrumental Music Teacher Lauren McCarthy introduced students who participated in the All-County Band. High School Band Teacher Steve Daniels and High School Chorus Teacher Tyler Young recognize the students who participated and were graded in the NYSSMA competition.

High School History Teacher Diane Brown discussed the success of a newly created cultural unit, she developed.

…………………………………………

The Annual School Budget Vote is next Tuesday, May 21, in the High School (follow the signs) from noon to 8 p.m.

On the Ballot besides the budget, voters will be asked to approve or disapprove: purchasing four diesel buses; establishment of a new technology equipment reserve; and the election of two members to the Board of Education. The names on the ballot are Justin Lilley and Kimberly Moore. Moore and Lilley both filed a petition for the position.

There is always room on the ballot for write-ins. Floyd Parker has thrown his hat in the ring.

Floyd told us that he has been asked to run. The reason he did not file petitions was because he thought that Derek Hartman was running again with Justin. “I didn’t find out that Derek wasn’t running until after it was too late to file” he said.

……………………………….

Maple Festival goers and the Maple Festival Committee have seen Bill Green, from Montour Falls, for many years at the Maple Festivals, but probably did not know his name. He began taking photos of the Festivals for Editor/Publisher Walter Grunfeld and has never stopped. The Publication Committee decided to do something special for this loyal volunteer. On Monday, Bill was treated to lunch at Reilly’s Café and received his official photographers pin. While here, he brought this year’s photos to share. Thank you Bill, next year you will be wearing this pin and folks will know who you are!

Work will begin this weekend on Alexander Votra’s Eagle Scout project on Lovell Field. Alexander will be renovating and upgrading the Lions Club’s Little League “Snack Shack” . We will have coverage of this worthwhile and much needed project, in next week’s blog.

Marathon Village Electric spent time this week on the public address system, which is heard throughout the Village. For a number of years the Memorial Day program has been difficult for many to hear and there have been complaints about the 1890 Union Fair commentary too. We hope that the upgrade and attention to this system will be an improvement.

The Village Electric Department does lots of different projects too. Here they are atop Corporation Hall tacking down fascia board.

Legion News

Friday night’s supper at the American Legion is chicken Alfredo with broccoli, just $14. The Ladies Auxiliary will be doing the cooking.

There will be a chicken BBQ on Saturday.

Flags will be placed on the graves of Veterans sometime next week, in preparation for Memorial Day. We will do a special “Neighborhood News” to give the day and time as soon as that has been decided.

There will be a Legion meeting on Monday, May 20th at 7 p.m.

There is no Friday night dinner on May 24. However, May 31 will be the Auxiliary’s famous fish dinner.

………………………..

Candidate for United States Senate, Mike Sapraicone was in Cortland County on Wednesday, May 8. He was interviewed by the Cortland Standard and WXHC, met the Mayor of Cortland and Marathon. His final stop in the County was Marathon, where he met members of the Baptist Church Board, then toured Lovell Field. Mike is a retired NYC Police Detective who established a security business after retirement. The Father of five grown children, his wife is a Supreme Court Justice.

Charles and Margaret Clark observed their 60th Wedding Anniversary on Thursday, May 16.

Looking for something to do on Saturdays? Check out the soccer games on Lovell Field, bring a chair and watch little folks chase the ball.

The Marathon Lions Club held their Annual Installation Dinner on Thursday, this week. The membership invited special guests. Mijo’s catered a delicious buffet featuring prime rib and grilled chicken.

Steve Robinson, President of the Lions Club welcomed all in attendance. Syd McEvoy presented the coveted Lion of the Year Award to Brian Card. In his remarks Syd said that Brian is one of the first to raise his hand to volunteer. Brian is willing to tackle any project from Little League to wearing the Lion costume at various events. (L-r) Syd McEvoy with Brian Card

It has been a Lion tradition at the Installation Banquet to honor a member of the community who has gone above and beyond in their participation in the community. The Community Service Award is given to someone who makes Marathon a good place to live. Lion Jim Robinson presented Mary Griep Bliss with a plaque and a $250 check to be given to the not-for-profit of Mary’s choice. (L-R) Jim Robinson, Mary and Steve Robinson.

President Steve Robinson, installed Justin Lilley as the new President and the following officers were also installed: 1st Vice President-Tim Farr, 2nd Vice President-Syd McEvoy, 3rd Vice President-Walter Vinson, Secretary-Lucas Baker, Treasurer-Jefferson Adams, Membership-Jody Hines, Lion Tamer-Bill McGovern, Safety Officer-Harold White, Robin Light-Tail Twister, Director One Year-Brian Card, Director 2 years-Eric St. Peter.

Secretary Lucas Baker announce the following members with perfect attendance and presented a pin. Steve Robinson-9 years, Jefferson Adams 13 years, Gary Cornell-46 years, Justin Lilley-13 years, Hunter White -2 years, Rob Light-23 years, Lucas Baker-4 years, Brian Card-2 years, Tim Farr-15 years, Harold White-28 years, Syd McEvoy-11 years, Jim Robinson -39 years.

Ed Tillotson holds the longest perfect attendance record with 49 years!

The evening concluded with lucky winners of a drawing taking home Gerber daisies.

We ask you to be a good neighbor and the check on your neighbor. Keep on spring cleaning, fling open the windows and doors, bring the smells of freshness into your living quarters. Don’t forget to vote and be ready to help place flags at the cemeteries. Until next time, put a song in your heart.

Feast your eyes! Oh how we rejoice in the renewal the coming of “things” like blossoms, buds and teeny tiny leaves that grow to the size of a hand! Have you toured down to Lovell Field? The trees there have come alive!

We are keeping fingers crossed that a frost will not kill the apple blossoms. No apples in the fall make for a sad season without them.

On Saturday, Town Supervisor Tim Elliott welcomed everyone to a special event to honor folks who have served the Town of Marathon. Due to covid some fine tributes were pushed aside, when these folks retired, but on Saturday the Town took care of the unfinished business.

Legislator George Wagner, Councilman Jim Dann, Highway Superintendent Randy Ensign (absent but represented his wife Joann) and Town Supervisor Tom Adams.

Special guest, Chairman of the Cortland County Legislature, Kevin Fitch of Scott attended the gathering and reminisced his working relationship with Legislator George.

Tom Adams with his family, Brian, Megan and wife Doris. Tom was a young father when he began with the Town Board, 41 years ago. He gave credit to others, referring to a team of volunteers, getting the job done.

Jim Dann with his wife Shari. Jim was first appointed to the Town Board to fill the vacancy of the death of Don Hines. He served 10 years.

In his absence, Randy Ensign’s daughter Carrie (l) and wife Joann ( R) were proud to accept his plaque.

Honored guests were each given an opportunity to speak as well as those in attendance. There was a spirit of community and good fellowship, as an attractive buffet of delicious foods were displayed and enjoyed.

School News

This has been Teacher Appreciation Week across the country and whether in school or out, most can fondly remember certain Teachers who influenced our lives. Each day something special was done to observe the Appreciation week, at our school. Monday was breakfast for teachers. Tuesday there were ice cream sundaes after school. Wednesday a special note. Thursday a gift and Friday the Board of Education is providing a catered lunch by Reilly’s Café. Congratulations to our teachers!

Many in the community, especially the parents of 2nd Graders, have been disturbed by a note the Second Grade parents received about Mother’s Day. We must write about this.

It sure looks like we have Second Grade Teachers who are “Woke Warriors” concerned with “society”. A note signed “kindly”, by The 2nd Grade Team, read this way-

“As we approach Mother’s Day, we have been thinking of a way that we could include diverse families that exist in our “society” today.”

The note went on to say for an alternative to the regular Mother’s Day card and craft that youngsters usually make, this time it would celebrate the “The Grown-ups Who Love us Day!”

Hmmm? Let that sink in! Sorry Mothers and Grandmothers, no cards for you. Now, if you do get a card it is because you are a grown-up, not a Mother or Grandmother.

Did Elementary Principal Hillis know about this note to parents? Did all Second Grade Teachers agree to send that note home? Perhaps these answers will be part of Monday’s meeting.

On Monday, at 6:30 p.m. in the High School Auditorium, there will be the Annual Hearing for the MCS School Budget and a “Meet the Candidate for the School Board”.

Following this, there will be a regular Board of Education meeting in the High School Library, at approximately 7 p.m. when there is a time for community comments.

It has been kind of quiet in the High School as the Senior Class trip to Florida is this week. We wish each one and the chaperones too, much fun and safe traveling.

…………………………………………

Meet the Great, Great Grandchildren Dr. Walter Dresel, Braeden and Eliana Richards of North Carolina who stopped by the 1861 Building on Thursday to see the Dresel paintings. The brother and sister duo are both interested in outdoor careers and will be camp counselors, this summer, in Texas at a huge Boy Scout Camping facility. We wish them successful travels and a wonderful experience this summer.

Laurie Tebbe returned home last Friday from a trip to Cedar Rapids Iowa, where she delivered the 1970’s Marathon Independent newspapers. Accompanying Laurie, were her brother Steve, his wife Jeannette and daughter Amy Tillotson. On the way they stayed a few days with Jeannette’s brother Larry Gaylord and his family, in Elgin, Illinois. In Galena, Illinois they visited President Grant’s home and had lunch at the DeSoto House Hotel, which was name for the discoverer of the Mississippi River. The DeSoto House Hotel was opened in April of 1855 and was billed as the “Largest Hotel in the West”. Crossing the Mississippi River into Dubuque, Iowa they spent the night in Cedar Rapids where they met and had dinner with Ryan Tillotson, former Marathon graduate and a cousin. The next day they deposited the Marathon Independents to be digitized and drove to Hannibal, Missouri to the Mark Twain’s home and visitor center. Next spending the night in St. Louis, Missouri they visited the arch at Gateway Arch National Park. Then on to Nashville, Tennessee, taking in a show at the Grand ole Opry and staying two nights at the Gaylord Opryland Hotel. While there they enjoyed a trolley ride around Nashville, visiting the Johnny Cash Museum, Antique Archeology Shop, Marathon Motor Museum and more. Then they traveled to Bowling Green, Kentucky where they entered Mammoth Caves, taking a 2 hour historical tour. They drove home after spending the night in Jeffersonville, Ohio. In short, when ever a person is with Laurie Tebbe, out in the big world, she packs in lots of historical adventures.

Another fellow on an adventure of a lifetime is Nelson Couch who is now sending photos from Africa. He writes “we are in Botswana at Thoma Telele near Maun. Horseback ride this morning. Certainly, in the outback, all dirt roads.”

Legion News

Commander Arnold is planning the Annual Memorial Day Ceremony and has announced that the Sheriff’s Department will escort the parade to and from the Cemetery. Everyone who can walk in the parade should make plans to do it this year. Make it a family tradition.

The Friday night menu, May 10th is scalloped potatoes and ham dinner, just $12.

…………………………

The handsome Tarbell Block has been sold to Mason and Lebron Properties, LLC of Ithaca. They are a young couple who want to renovate & restore the building. Marathon folks fondly remember the improvements that Howard and Kathy Dennison made to that building. It is one of Marathon’s last grand buildings in the center of the business district.

The Maple Festival Committee met on Thursday this week. It was motioned and agreed that all officers remain in their office. Co-Chairs-Paige Parker & Josh Ensign, Secretary-Michelle Steven McGrath and Treasurer- Michelle Bleck Caughey. In other Festival news the 2025 Festival will be held on April 5 & 6. Pancakes made outside worked quite well and will be moved closer to the cafeteria door next year. The Treasurer’s report was not accepted at this time. The committee agreed to host “An Evening on the Green” with Peck Memorial Library this summer. The next meeting will be on September 12.

Sympathy of the community is extended to the family and friends of Tony Merihew who passed away on Sunday, May 5, 2024 at the Guthrie Cortland Nursing & Rehabilitation Center at the age of 93. Most folks didn’t know that his real name – his given name was Glenn. A farm boy, born in the Town of Freetown to Benton and Ruby Goddard Merihew, he was raised with siblings Marion, Pete, Carl, Louise, Norma and Paul.

We cannot remember Marathon without Tony and Joan Merihew, who have been married 74 years. Folks always said “Tony and Joan” or “Jaon and Tony” as they were always together, especially in their older years. Certainly a life time resident of the area, he was a businessman, a leader, a volunteer, and faithful to his family and friends.

People liked to see him coming. Active in the Marathon Fire Department, he is a former Chief. He and Joan built a handsome log cabin on Albro Hill, but after some time they moved from the Main Road, for more privacy. Tony enjoyed having a number of animals that he loved to watch over and care for.

The Father of three daughters, Barbara, Connie and Susan, Tony is survived by them and his wife Joan; brother Pete and sister Marion Barrows; 11 grandchildren; 18 great grandchildren and 8 great-great-grandchildren; as well as nieces, nephews and cousins.

Services will be held, this Saturday at Marathon Memorial Chapel (May 11, 2024) with Brother Tom Boice officiating. Tony’s family will receive friends from 11 a.m. until the 1 p.m. service. In honor of Tony’s memory, expressions of sympathy may be directed to the Marathon Fire Department, P.O. Box 488 or to MAVAC, P. O. Box 132, Marathon, NY 13803.

As Mother’s Day approaches, we think about that family day in our house on Academy Street, so many years ago. Perhaps it was first a bouquet of violets picked by little hands, a hug, a kiss, a homemade card, maybe a goofy poem that made her laugh. Yes, like the old TV show says “I Remember Mama” and in fact we all do.

We ask you to be a good neighbor and to check on your neighbor. We hope you “Remember MaMa” always, and of course Mother’s Day is a perfect reminder. Until next time, count your blessings!

Tra-la it is spring !

The first one to report seeing a trillium was Mayor Scott Chamberlin who goes for a walk around town every day. He ventured down Burroughs Road last week and there in the woods he spied a white trillium. Don’t know what they look like? Well here is one found by this reporter, who ventured in the woods on West Hill.

So while most folks are enjoying the tulips and daffodils along walkways and landscaped areas, we want you to know there is blooming going on where the wild things grow.

On Monday the Historical Society was pleased to learn the history of Killawog Cemetery, Parker Street Cemetery and the Marathon Cemetery. Donna Barrows of the Killawog Cemetery wrote a fine report which was read in her absence, due to her previous commitment to MAVAC. Karen Knapp, (R) the Secretary/Treasuer of the Marathon Cemetery Association and Roland Robinson (L) President of the Parker Street Cemetery shared the history and their association with each cemetery.

On Wednesday, May 1st Peck Memorial Library was decked out for May Day. Patrons and guests enjoyed springtime cookies and lemonade. The Open House debuted the summer reading program “Adventures Begin At The Library” is the theme. Library Director Mary Frank (L) and Donna Hughes (right) are always ready to accommodate all who enter our wonderful Library. Trustee Dan McConnell was ready to read a story and this young lady is taking the books she chose home for reading.

On Thursday the Terry Hammond’s Christian Academy Pre-Schoolers were on a mission to mail a letter and explore the Post Office. Each child had at least one letter and money to buy a stamp. Our wonderful Post Office Ladies (Amy and Karen) were ready to accommodate the little patrons. Amy brought out a stole so they could reach the counter and do business. There were plenty of pleases and thank you’s said. The letters were stamped and put in the box. Then the jolly little group walked back to school to enjoy a pizza party.

On Thursday afternoon Sam and Genevieve Geer and their business “Le Puppet Regime” located in the Marathon railroad depot received visitors who brought them special recognition as Cortland County’s Small Business of the Year for National Small Business Week.

Their business began in Philadelphia and moved to Marathon about two years ago. Together they create glass and metal products capturing the imagination of art enthusiasts.

In speaking at the reception, Genevieve shared that New York State has helped the company develop a better business plan. She credited the Onondaga Watertown Small Business Development Center ( part of Cortland County’s MAP Grant application process). Olympian Lane is a new name!

They did it!! Appleby Teacher, Christine Brandstadt’s 5th Grade students did something that is historic! They named the circle drive to Appleby Elementary School! Here is how that happened. For a number of years, Mrs. Brandstadt has arranged for her students to tour the Village of Marathon, exploring its history. This year her students were especially curious and fascinated by their hometown. One day in class, Khloe McAllister asked if the circle drive to the elementary school was named? When she found out that it was not, she thought that since the drive around the High School has been named Park Street, the drive to her school should be named too. That began a series of exciting events. Brainstorming names for the driveway, then asking the elementary school students to vote, presenting to the Board of Education and finally the decision of Olympian Lane was made. Here are the presenters to the Board of Education on April 15th. (l to r) Khloe McAllister, Daniel Byron, Mrs. Brandstadt, Colton Fiske, Bailey Quail and Tanner Coleman.

Sympathy of the community is extended to Joe Caughey and his family upon the death of his Father, Stephen Caughey of Cortland. Mr. Caughey passed away, April 18, he was 72. A family man, fun and witty, he enjoyed fishing and hunting. His obituary reads “in lieu of flowers, go throw a ball with a kid, take someone fishing or go for a walk in the woods.”

There are few folks in Marathon who will remember a Dr. Frail and his office on Brink Street. No doubt folks have heard his name. He had two daughters who started school here in Marathon. The family moved to Cortland in 1940. The sisters kept their fond childhood memories of growing up on Brink Street and often visited Marathon. Catherine and Alice in their older years lived together on Greenbush Street in Cortland. Notice of Alice’s death was posted this week, she was 86. She married, had three daughters, a 35 year marriage, became a widow in 1997. Holding 2 Masters (Education & French) she had a distinguish teaching career. We remember her enthusiasm during the taping of the Historical Society’s “The Brink Street Gang”.

Sympathy of the community is extended to the family and friends of Frederick “Fred” R. Niggli, age 89, the youngest child born to the late Ralph and Alice Niggli. His siblings were Bob, Warren, Betty and Dick, who have all passed away. Fred grew up in the house now owned and occupied by Terry and David Light. That house is rather well known in the community for its stone front. It was Fred’s father Ralph, a stone mason, who designed and laid the stone front. Now years later, David Light will attest that not one stone has fallen out or become corrupted. Fred and his brother Dick became masons like their Father. A Niggli in the Town of Marathon has a good reputation for knowing how to do things and doing them right.

A Korean War Veteran, following Air Force duty, Fred was a self employed mason. In later years, he retired from Marathon Schools. He and his late wife Jane were married 61 years. Fred is survived by his son Fred and his daughters Laurie, Lisa and Carolee; 7 grandchildren;1 great grandchild; nieces and nephews.

There will be a memorial service on Saturday, May 4th, noontime at Point Bible Church in Whitney Point.
